entry.title: New Workflow Service for SAP Ariba Category Management in 2508: Key Changes and Actions Required
entry.content:
The August 2025 release of SAP Ariba Category Management will introduce an architectural update designed to strengthen workflow capabilities by leveraging the SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) service. While there won’t be a change for business users, it is essential for admins to make specific updates to their current tenants. These updates will ensure that workflow processes related to strategy and plan document approvals continue to work.

In this blog post, we’ll walk you through the key changes related to the new SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) service and highlight the actions required before and after the release date on August 15, 2025.

Pre-Release: Withdraw Documents that Are Pending Approval

With the move to the SBPA service, any approval documents that were submitted before August 15 and are still pending approval won’t be processed by the new workflow service. As a result, approvers won’t be able to take any action (approve or reject) on these documents. Therefore, approvers must accept or reject these documents or the respective document owners must withdraw their documents before August 15, 2025.

Once the new workflow service is released on August 15, the documents can be resubmitted to trigger approvals with the new SBPA service.

Post-Release: Update Role Collections and User Groups for Workflow Apps

Transitioning to the SBPA service involves changes in role assignments to ensure seamless access and functionality. Please note that the fact that the Monitor Workflow Instances and My Inbox apps are visible to business users, doesn’t guarantee that they can access the apps. 

As a business admin for SAP Ariba Category Management, you must update the relevant role collections or user groups (depending on your setup) to make sure that business users can continue to use the workflow apps after August 15. Do the following, depending on whether you're using role collections or user groups:

 Access to Monitor Workflow Instances appAccess to My Inbox app
Setup with role collectionsAssign the new ProcessAutomationAdmin role collection to the relevant business users.Assign the new ProcessAutomationParticipant role collection to the relevant business users.
Setup with user groups

Ensure that the IAS user group CategoryManagementWorkflowAdministrator is mapped to the BTP role collection Category Management Workflow Administrator.

Ensure that the IAS user group CategoryStrategyApprover is mapped correctly to the corresponding BTP role collection Category Strategy Approver.

Changes to Email Notification Setup

Email notifications are integral to workflow updates. Whether or not you must change your settings post-release depends on whether SAP Ariba Category Management was provisioned in an SAP-managed SAP BTP account (simplified provisioning) or a customer-managed SAP BTP account (manual provisioning).

SAP-managed SAP BTP accounts

No action needed as email notifications work without manual setup.

Customer-managed SAP BTP accounts

Admins must manually configure the email destination post-release. For more information, see Setting Up an SAP BTP Destination for Email Notifications.

New, Built-In SMTP Server

With the new SBPA service, SAP introduces a built-in SMTP server, simplifying email notifications. After the August 15 release, all customers without prior SMTP configuration will automatically receive notifications from noreply-categorymanagement@notifications.sap.com.

Note

Make sure to whitelist noreply-categorymanagement@notifications.sap.com in your corporate email system to avoid missing crucial notifications.

You still have the flexibility to configure your own SMTP server, whether cloud-based or on-premise, depending on your organizational preferences. If you have configured an SMTP server and want to continue using it, you need to create a new destination SAP_Business_Notifications_Mail . For more information, see Configure an SMTP Mail Destination.

If you used your own SMTP server before and want to move to the new default option, you need to delete email destination bpmworkflowruntime_mail.

Conclusion

The integration of the new SBPA workflow service brings efficiency and ease to workflow management in SAP Ariba Category Management. It is imperative to update roles and address email notification setup (if needed) to maintain business continuity. By following the steps outlined in this blog post, you ensure a smooth transition and maximum benefit from the new service.

For more information, see the following resources on SAP Help Portal:

  • Integration of SAP Build Process Automation for Workflow Management in SAP Ariba Category Management
  • User Management

entry.title: Analytical Query: Annotations for Filter by Measure
entry.content:
Hello All, 

I have built a Analytical Query using CDS. I have a requirement to automatically filter out data, which doesn't match specific conditions in few of the Columns(measures).

For eg. assume the condition is to exclude rows wherever Delta is 0

Col1Col2Col3Val1Val2Delta
ABE12-1
ABD220
ACD211
GCE422
GCF330

Depending which Characteristic columns user chooses columns to display, Delta column may result in various values.

Col1Val1Val2Delta
A550
G752
Col3Val1Val2Delta
D431
E541
F330
Col2Col3Val1Val2Delta
BD220
BE12-1
CD211
CE422
CF330

I can achieve this requirement by using "Filter by Measures" at runtime. Is there a way to achieve this via ABAP CDS annotations?

Thank You

Cc: copying some blog authors here for their advice @AndreaUS @joerg_franke @MarkGreen

entry.title: Re: Draft Goods Issue document is created with same draft...
entry.content:
Hi @Underdog ,

The Document No. It is actually the next document number available for that object. In the case below, 1242 is the next DocNum available for Sales Orders, so all drafts will get the same until a new SO is posted and it moves to the next. SAP handles the number association when you post the draft, in case it changes from creation to posting.

Regarding a way out, I don't think you can change the standard subject in the message. Maybe you could customise the approval request message to bring some more details for the approver.  If you have B1UP it's achievable. Or, you might use a custom Add-On for this purpose. 

I hope it helps

BR,
Felipe

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud: Embedded Steampunk: C1 Released Contract
entry.content:
Hi, working on s4 private cloud 2023 with the project pushing on clean core and so strict that we cant simply wrap any underlying cds or object release for tier 1 usage, that is quite a painful path.

In 2023 fps2, still quite a lot cds only released for key user, not cloud programming. And for a very simple requirement update maintenance notification, the released BO does not cover long text update, but quite strange is the API able to support long text update. 

And also there is no released cds to get all the maintenance order operation included deleted operation. This causing issue for us to use EML BO to add new operation as we need to determine the largest use operation number and get next available number for the EML input.


We could raise CI but project timeline will not wait, still have to go live on time. 

Probably would think is wise to just mass release all the object already released to key user, also released for cloud programming.

hopefully this suggestion can be considered as SAP keep selling the clean core concept to the customer.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Hyderabad 2025: A Day of Learning, Laughter, and Lasting Connections
entry.content:
The SAP Inside Track (SIT) Hyderabad event on July 26, 2025, was a vibrant blend of learning, networking, and memorable experiences. With an impressive lineup of sessions and a buzzing crowd of SAP professionals and enthusiasts, the day unfolded as a celebration of knowledge, innovation, and community spirit. 

Kicking Off with Purpose: Sindhu Sets the Tone

The day began with an inspiring address by Sindhu Gangadharan, SVP & MD, SAP Labs India, who eloquently captured the essence of SAP Inside Track. She outlined the agenda and emphasized the event’s core vision - a dynamic platform for SAP professionals and passionate learners to connect, collaborate, and grow. Her words set a strong, uplifting tone, and the enthusiasm in the room was immediately evident.

The sessions lined up as shared in the official blog post covered a rich spectrum of topics, offering something for everyone, whether you were diving deep into SAP BTP, ABAP RESTful Application Programming, or exploring Gen AI and other emerging technologies.

Beyond Presentations – A Celebration of Community

The insightful sessions were only part of what made the day special. What truly elevated the experience was the energy and collegiality of the SAP community. The event thrived on the shared passion of its participants, and the seamless execution was a testament to the unwavering dedication of the organizers, content curators, and volunteers. Being part of the event as a volunteer made it even more meaningful for me, as contributing behind the scenes and spending the day with such a dedicated, driven community was incredibly rewarding.

Engaging conversations both technical and personal sparked genuine connection throughout the day. It felt more like a gathering of curious, like-minded individuals than a formal conference. Reconnecting with familiar faces and forming new ones added a personal warmth that made the experience all the more meaningful.

A Perfect Blend of Work and Play

SIT Hyderabad struck just the right balance between learning and fun. A casual quiz kept the crowd engaged, while the spin-the-wheel added surprise and laughter - by luck, I even won a round! These lighthearted elements fostered camaraderie and reminded us that truly memorable events blend intellectual engagement with moments of delight.

Gratitude and Anticipation

Deep appreciation to the speakers, volunteers, and participants who made SIT Hyderabad exceptional. The community’s passion and insight left me inspired and enriched. I depart with valuable knowledge and meaningful connections, eagerly awaiting the next chapter of this shared journey.

Warm Regards,

Vidya Chandran

entry.title: Re: Procurement of Services in SAP Ariba
entry.content:
Automatic Generation of Service Sheets

In Ariba B&I, there is a provision to automatically generate SES based on Invoices. This solution can be adapted to various scenarios, allowing for enhanced flexibility and efficiency in your processes.

For more information you can visit - Automatic Generation of Service Sheets | SAP Help Portal

Prerequisites –

Have your Designated Support Contact (DSC) to file a case to enable required features/parameters. - https://me.sap.com/notes/KB0405882

After the required features/parameters are enabled further you can check and apply below pointers as per your business use case -

  1. Auto-generate service sheets from service invoices. (This transaction rule is mandatory for the Auto-SES feature)
  2. Require suppliers to provide description for ad-hoc line item (This transaction rule will make product description field mandatory for suppliers while creating Service Entry Sheet for Unplanned service items.)
  3. By enabling a transaction rule ‘Do not allow suppliers to manually create service entry sheets for service orders’, the buyer can prevent suppliers from creating service entry sheets. As a result, the "Create Service Sheet" button on Purchase Order UI of SAP Business Network Supplier Account will become grayed out.
  4. Supplier initiated service entry sheet for unplanned service item may get stuck with an error ‘Non catalog item associated with service line number 1 is not allowed’, to avoid this you can refer - https://me.sap.com/notes/KB0396631

When the Invoice is submitted in Ariba B&I it will be updated with status ‘Awaiting Service Sheet Approval’ (Refer below screenshot) if there is an approval flow configured for Service Entry Sheet. Following service entry sheet approval, the standard invoice flow will be followed.

Invoice Status in Ariba B&I

Like this, if a supplier submits an invoice from their SAP Business Network supplier account, it will have the status ‘Pending Approval’ (Refer below screenshot) and won't be sent to Ariba B&I until SES has been approved by buyer.

Invoice status in SAP Business Network Supplier Portal

entry.title: SAP TM Transportation Proposal
entry.content:
Hello experts

We are implementing SAP TM basis in S/4 with a multi road scenario, so, form the same Surce Location and Destionation location we can have multiple routing:

ex:

Source A/ Destination B

Route 1: A->C->D->B

Route 2: A->C->E->B

We found out the possibility to have, for a TU or FU a transportation proposal (without creating a default route) that should provide to us all the possible routing for Source A e Destination B.

At the moment we do not have an optimizer engine installed so:

Can we have this transportation proposal without an optimizer engine?

There is a guide that can help us to customize correctly the transportation proposal?

 

At the moment we are not able to ave any result even we created:

- Trade lines

- Transhipment location.

Can anybody help me?

Best regards

Marco

entry.title: Re: How to stop the Zero amt settlement document in the c...
entry.content: You can prevent zero-amount credit memos by enabling the “Skip zero net value” flag in your settlement document type and adjusting your condition contract filter for net value > 0. In SPRO → Logistics General → Settlement Management → Check settlement document type settings. Activate “Do not create for 0 net value” (may differ by release). If still triggered, use BAdI WS_SCDS_SETTLEMENT to skip zero-value items.

entry.title: Re: How to stop the Zero amt settlement document in the c...
entry.content:
@vijaya_kumar5 

You can prevent zero-amount credit memos by enabling the “Skip zero net value” flag in your settlement document type and adjusting your condition contract filter for net value > 0.

  • In SPRO → Logistics General → Settlement Management → Check settlement document type settings.

  • Activate “Do not create for 0 net value” (may differ by release).

  • If still triggered, use BAdI WS_SCDS_SETTLEMENT to skip zero-value items.

entry.title: Re: Plan & Budget import financial data in Public cloud
entry.content:
Hi @Keratiya_D 

Thank you for the question.

Generally, this is what you need to know about how plan data import functions:

  • The third line of the CSV template mainly defines the combination of Plan Category, Fiscal Year, and Project scope.
  • If any filename includes the same scope values, the system will overwrite existing entries for those scope criteria. That means it will replace previous year's data.

To avoid this when uploading current year only:

  • Use distinct scope values for each year. For example, import 2024 with scope = PLN + 2024, and later import 2025 with scope = PLN + 2025.
  • Ensure the Plan Category and Fiscal Year fields in the template remain unique per file.

Here are my suggested steps:

First, split by Fiscal Year Scope

  • Ensure to use separate scope combinations per year especially in the third line of each import file.
  • For example, import 2024 upfront, then later import 2025 with a different scope.
  • This measure ensures that data for one fiscal year does not override another.

Secondly, use the Fiori UI to confirm before import

    • When importing the required data, carefully review the Plan Data Scope preview to ensure only the current year scope is affected.

Finally, ensure to maintain prior year imports as separate scope entries

    • Make sure not to use the same Plan Category + Fiscal Year combination in multiple files unless you want to replace that year’s data.

Applying this approach allows you to preserve previous year data and only add or update the current year plan/budget.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Where can I start learning to set up SAP Commerce Cloud to enable buyers and sellers to interact?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Exploring the Fundamentals of Setting up and Running SAP Commerce Cloud in a B2B Environment learning journey.

Overview
At the end of this course, the learner will be able to set up SAP Commerce Cloud to enable buyers and sellers to interact in a B2B environment.

Learning objectives
After completing this course, the learner will be able to:

  • Construct the merchant sales organization including users and spend thresholds.
  • Reproduce the customer purchasing organization in the My Company Section of SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Employ the storefront order process, including cart assembly, checkout, approval and quote negotiations. 
  • Describe that integrated buying is supported in SAP Commerce Cloud via Punchout support.

Prerequisites

  • Understanding the Purpose of SAP Commerce Cloud, its Components and User Roles​
  • Comparing E-Commerce in SAP Commerce Cloud for B2B and B2C

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio – my notes
entry.content:
In my previous blog post Using Python in SAP Business Application Studio – my notes, I focused on Python.

This blog post focuses on running Jupyter notebooks in SAP Business Application Studio (referred to as "BAS" below). I assume you're not an absolute beginner with SAP Business Application Studio—or at least you're familiar with Visual Studio Code. If you need a general introduction to navigating, coding, and executing code in notebooks using the Jupyter extension, then check: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/datascience/jupyter-notebooks#_create-or-open-a-jupyter-notebook 

For the examples in this post, I’ll be using the SAP Business Application Studio, which is available in the SAP BTP Trial environment.

Creating a virtual environment with the Python extension

As already discussed in Persisting Python environment when using Jupyter notebooks in SAP Business Application Studio, one of the first things you might want to do, when working with the Python code in BAS, is to create a virtual environment. There, we discussed how to use the `python -m venv` command to create it. Now, let's use the extension commands.

🤓 Pro tip: if you want to understand what is happening when extension commands are executed, then:

  1. Open the Output panel (eg, View -> Output from the menu).
  2. Choose the output for the Python extension, and then in Settings, set the level to Info and Set As Default:

     

  3. Alternatively, if the Python extension has not yet been loaded, then open the command palette and run the command >Python: Show Output:

Go to the command palette and run the command `Python: Create Environment...`...

..and select the Venv option to create a virtual environment `.venv` (the name cannot be modified, at least in the current version of the Python extension):

...selecting the required base Python run-time installation (like ~/.asdf-inst/shims/python😞

If you have set output on the Info level for the Python extension, then you should see (interesting) details on how the environment was created:

One additional note: the .gitignore file has been automatically created for the virtual environment:

Select the Jupyter kernel

To execute code in your Jupyter notebook, you need to select a Jupyter kernel that will be used to execute the code.

Click Select Kernel and then on Python Environments... category:

...which will show you the list of Python environments that the Python extension found in your BAS dev space. Click on your virtual environment created for your project, like .venv:

Execute code in a Jupyter notebook

During the first execution of your code, Jupyter will check if the IPython Kernel executable (the Python package ipykernel) is installed in the selected Python environment. If not, it will automatically install it, as can be seen in the Jupyter extension's output, and then start it:

Once started, the Kernel exposes 5 ports for communication with your notebook, which can be seen in the run-time specification in a file ~/.local/share/jupyter/runtime/kernel-*.json. While this information should not be required in most of the basic scenarios, you might find it overwhelming that BAS displays pop-up messages for each port every time the kernel runtime starts:

While information about open ports is relevant when developing front-end applications using SAP Business Application Studio, it might be useless and overwhelming when working with Jupyter notebooks. So, click on the settings icon and turn off notifications from the "Exposing router ports" extension or disable this extension completely:

Limiting listed Python environments

You might also find it quite overwhelming to deal with the list of all the global Python locations when setting the kernel for a notebook. To reduce this list, select the command Jupyter: Filter Kernels from the command palette:

...which opens the setting jupyter.kernels.excludePythonEnvironments. Switch to the Workspace tab and click Add Item to specify which Python environments to exclude from the list. You might want to add the following items to the list:

/bin/python3
/usr/bin/python3
~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3.13
~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3
~/.asdf-inst/shims/python

🤓Pro tip: these values can also be edited in the project's file .vscode/settings.json.

{
    "jupyter.kernels.excludePythonEnvironments": [
        "/bin/python3",
        "/usr/bin/python3",
        "~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3.13",
        "~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3",
        "~/.asdf-inst/shims/python"
    ]
}

Next time you need to pick the kernel for a Jupyter notebook, you should see only your project's virtual Python environment:

You should be ready to work with your Jupyter notebooks in SAP Business Application Studio!

Please share your tips in the comments!

------

-Vitaliy, aka @Sygyzmundovych

entry.title: Re: Custom Tile Visualization & Navigation in SAP Build Workzone - Cloud foundry launchpad: Solv
entry.content:
Wow, thanks a lot for this tutorial @Kamakhya! I've been looking for exactly this. 

I do have a basic question though, for which I haven't found a clear cut answer in the documentation. As of today, what is the best practice to deploy content such as dynamic and custom tiles? Is it a content-package, or GACD module com.sap.application.content? I am asking because I keep seeing written that content packages are the way forward, but they don't seem to be deployable through traditional CI/CD pipelines! Using the UI of the BPT cockpit to deploy content-packages manually does not seem like a good practice to me. 

If you have any insight on this matter, it would be greatly appreciated.

Cheers, 

Theodore

entry.title: Re: How to create a checkbox in SAPSCRIPT and see it via print preview
entry.content: Did you try to generate the PDF via the command field PDF! ? The exclamation mark is to be included. Note that Print Preview is different from printing, it's not WYSIWYG, you can't expect to obtain the same result. Even with PDF! The only true WYSIWYG is the one done by Windows, by "printing" (not printing in fact) to a local printer (defining the printer with __DEFAULT in the transaction SPAD).

entry.title: Best learning content marketplace to integrate with SF as per your experience ?
entry.content:
Hello, 

We are looking for a partner to enrich our learning content catalogue and we have been looking at options such as SkillSoft, LinkedIn, Go1, Litmos and many more. We need to be able to provide content in French and English as a minimum as we have a strong presence in Quebec but also accross Canada and the States.

We would like to have a partner that increases our learner's experience but also simplifies our learning content management.   Few roadbloacks were encountered and I would appreciate if you could share your experience or advice on the choice you made and why?

We discovered some painpoint rendering our decision harder:

- lack of localization of title and description once imported in SF (our employees must be able to search in both French and english)

- Random Item ID clashing with our naming convention and making reporting analysis and grouping harder

- Limited data returning to SF, only completion status. 

 

Thanks a lot!

entry.title: Re: Node.js @sap/hana-client 2.25.29 getting strange erro...
entry.content: Hello, after an investigation by the Security Team who's responsible for this component, the root cause has been located. They've pushed a change for fixing. We'll provide further update when the patch with this fix is released. For your reference, "[t]he problem here is, that the SECUDIR environment variable is set. So the client tries to load the SAP CommonCryptoLib. But the lib could not be loaded, probably because the sapcrypto.dll was not found. And we recently introduced that we crash/throw when the SAP CCL cannot be loaded." Thus, w.r.t workarounds, in addition to explicitly set the crypto provider to "mscrypto" by `sslCryptoProvider`, you can undefine `SECUDIR`.

Its based on the scenario :
HANA Modelling is used when you are working outside of ABAP, e.g. in a pure HANA XS or custom cloud app stack
HANA Live is used for legacy systems (i.e. ECC on HANA)

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 - DTW - Purchasing UOM Codes
entry.content:
Hi @bbranco 

Thanks for all the detail. This helps pinpoint exactly where the issue is. Based on how SAP Business One handles DTW imports of UoM group assignments, here's the situation and how to resolve it:

SAP Business One requires that the “Default” UoM entry referenced in your DTW template (DefaultPurchasingUoMEntry and DefaultSalesUoMEntry) already exists in the item’s UoM list. If you reference an entry for example the “entry 8” that hasn’t been created in that item’s unit-of-measure list, DTW fails with this error. See the following links.  How to DTW item with multiple UOM   &   DTW OBCD Bar Codes

However, in your case, referencing UoM group entry 8 for 6-CS/PK failed because that entry was not yet present in the item’s UoM collection before you attempted to assign it.

Here’s what’s happening in SAP Business One DTW imports:

  • The error “Default UoM must be defined” appears because you're referencing a UoM entry (entry 8, 6-CS/PK) that doesn’t exist in the item's UoM list yet.
  • SAP requires that the UoM entry is already created first (via ITM12 template) before setting it as default in the item master.

Here’s what I suggest:

  1. Use a DTW ITM12 template to add entry 8 (6-CS/PK, qty 6) to item 20011C.
  2. Once this UoM is present, run your second DTW to set DefaultPurchasingUoMEntry = 8 (and/or DefaultSalesUoMEntry = 8).

 

Below are more detailed steps to avoid the error:

First, create the new UoM group entry (e.g. 6-CS/PK, value 6) for the item using DTW or via the SAP UI before assigning it as default.
Use the ITM12 template in DTW to add a record: ItemCode, UoMGroupEntry, Price, PurchaseUnit, SalesUnit... 20011C, 8, , 6-CS/PK, 6-CS/PK. This ensures the new UoM entry exists in the item’s UoM table.

Secondly, make sure to upload that ITM12 template first, which populates the UoM list for the item.

Finally, run your second DTW file that references that UoM entry as the DefaultPurchasingUoMEntry = 8 or DefaultSalesUoMEntry = 8. Once entry 8 exists in the item’s UoM list, DTW will successfully assign it as the default without error.

This step sequence ensures the referenced default UoM entry exists and resolves the validation error.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP S4HANA Service Documented Credit Decisions
entry.content:
Documented Credit Decisions App in FIORI is used see blocked transactions (Service orders, Service Contracts) due to credit limit Exposure under “Documented credit Decisions” (DCD) FIORI App. 

Below Steps to Enable the DCD app in FIORI:

1. To Enable the FIORI App, User has to assigned the Business Role "SAP_BR_CREDIT_CONTROLLER " .
2. Check and if required activate BC Set - UKM_DCD_CUST      
3. Activate the Event Type CL_UKM_DCD_WF_EVENT using Transaction SWE2 
4. Verify and if not create the Number range for the Case ID

 

 


6. User can verify the blocked transactions due to credit check failure using                        

Transaction SCASE 

 

Happy Blogging,

Azad Mishra

Currently, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition does not support entering multiple monthly budget lines in one screen; each budget must be entered separately per posting date, though you can use the Copy Budget function or upload multiple lines via API or Excel template as a workaround

Thanks for detailed blog about the Access Policies feature. We have implemented this on our tenant, and it works as expected.

Here's still a room to improve this Access Policies. When a policy is applied to Package or to artifact, only assigned users have create/edit/delete authorization while other tenant users still have read access to the resources, which we think can be improved. Only assigned users should see the packages or iflows (any resources) to the attached policy. In a way, access policies can be improved further on the action granularity as well.

Kindly let us know what you think.

Regards,
Pratik

entry.title: Re: Auditing Solution Update for SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform 4.3 +

I find that the duration is accurate for reports with 1 query. However, if there is more than 1 the Event Duration multiplies by the number of queries in the report. So, a report's duration with 4 queries that runs in 1 minute, shows 4 minutes on the audit report. So you know of a way to account for this situation? Thank you!  Below is a photo of the query.

entry.title: Mozambique: Upcoming legal mandate about certification of billing Software and SAF-T File reporting
entry.content:
Dear SAP customers in Mozambique,

We would like to bring to your attention an important upcoming legal change regarding the certification of billing software and SAF-T (Standard Audit File for Tax) file reporting. While the full details of the law are not yet published, we want to inform you about the current status and where to find the latest information.

Key Points

  1. Current status of the law: We are currently aware of a proposed version of the law text. However, the final requirements and conditions are yet to be officially published.
  2. Reporting of billing data: Starting from April 2025, businesses in Mozambique are expected to report their billing data to the tax authorities. During this initial phase, the reports can be submitted in any format, such as Excel.
  3. Official Information Source: For the most up-to-date and detailed information, we recommend visiting the Mozambique Tax Authorities’ dedicated page at saft-mz.com. This page will be updated with the latest developments regarding this legal change.

SAP Localization Status

It is important to note that Mozambique is not a localized country for SAP. As such, SAP does not have plans to deliver localized solutions for this market at this time.

Stay Informed

We recommend regularly checking the Mozambique Tax Authorities’ page and staying in touch with your legal advisors to ensure you have the most current information about the upcoming legal changes.

This blog is intended to serve as an informative resource for our customers in Mozambique. As we learn more about the specifics of the new law, we will continue to update you

We will keep you posted as more information becomes available.

 

DISCLAIMER. 
The links in the blog are external, so they may be modified at any time externally without previous notice. 
This blog is meant for legal information purposes. It does not define any commitment to develop or deliver any of the functionality mentioned above.

entry.title: From Mechanical Engineering to SAP: My Journey, Challenges, and the Next Step to a PhD
entry.content:
The Spark That Led Me to SAP

It all started with a fascination for systems—the kind that drive industries, make businesses run efficiently, and enable people to work smarter, not harder. As a Mechanical Engineering student, I was trained to optimize processes and troubleshoot problems. But when I stumbled upon SAP during my Master's degree in Industrial Systems Management, I realized this was the tool I had been looking for all along.

I still remember the first time I saw SAP in action. It was during a project on supply chain optimization, where SAP S/4HANA MM was used to streamline inventory and procurement processes. The complexity and potential of the system fascinated me. I was immediately hooked. The transition from mechanical systems to ERP systems like SAP S/4HANA MM wasn’t just an academic shift; it was a career-defining moment. SAP’s ability to manage procurement, inventory, and maintenance processes sparked a passion for digital transformation in industries that had yet to unlock their full potential.

Why SAP? The Game-Changer in Business Processes

Throughout my academic journey, I always sought ways to make processes more efficient. In Mechanical Engineering, it was about optimizing physical systems; in SAP, it was about optimizing digital systems that connect an entire organization’s operations. As an SAP S/4HANA MM certified consultant, I dove into procurement cycles, inventory management, and maintenance processes. One of the most rewarding moments was when I applied my SAP knowledge in a real-world simulation, extracting data from SAP and designing workflow processes that mimicked real business scenarios. The experience sharpened both my technical and analytical skills.

But what excites me most is not just the theory behind these processes—it’s the tangible, real-world impact. I’ve seen firsthand how the integration of SAP can elevate businesses, creating a seamless, efficient workflow that improves everything from stock management to procurement strategies. For instance, during my internship at OCP Group, I had the chance to help streamline their procurement process using SAP S/4HANA MM, which resulted in a 10% reduction in inventory holding costs over six months. This is where SAP truly becomes a transformation engine for businesses, driving measurable improvements in efficiency and cost savings.

The Shift: From Consultant to Scholar

As I reflect on my journey, I find myself at a crossroads. I’ve honed my skills in SAP and project management, but my academic curiosity is pushing me toward a deeper exploration. This is where the PhD dilemma comes into play.

I’m contemplating two distinct paths for my PhD:

  1. Exploring the Impact of SAP in Digital Transformation: This would allow me to combine my expertise in SAP S/4HANA MM with my passion for process optimization, diving deeper into how SAP can drive change in the procurement and maintenance sectors. I’d explore how ERP systems, like SAP, can be fully leveraged to improve supply chain efficiency, reduce costs, and enable smarter decision-making across industries.

  2. Innovations in Systems Management and Reliability: With my background in Industrial Systems Management and FMEA analysis, this route would allow me to continue to focus on engineering systems, but with a heavy emphasis on how emerging technologies like ERP systems, AI, and IoT can improve reliability and reduce failure in industrial processes. This would combine my engineering background with my interest in digital systems and process optimization.

The Tough Decision: Which Path Should I Choose?

This is where I need your help. As I stand at this academic crossroads, I’m torn between these two exciting directions for my PhD. Should I dig deeper into the world of SAP, expanding its impact on businesses and industries? Or should I return to my engineering roots and explore how technology can improve reliability and innovation in industrial systems?

I’d love to hear from fellow professionals, academics, and SAP experts. What path would you choose, and why? How have your experiences shaped your decision-making when it comes to advancing your career and academic goals?

For anyone who's walked a similar path, what resources or strategies helped you as you navigated this transition from hands-on application to academic research? Any tips or advice would be greatly appreciated!

Conclusion: The Journey Continues

Every career is an ongoing journey, and mine is no different. From discovering SAP to contemplating a PhD, each step has been a learning experience. With every project I take on, I find myself more inspired to explore the full potential of SAP and its role in shaping the future of industries.

As I continue to seek knowledge and push the boundaries of what I can achieve, I look forward to engaging with the SAP community and drawing inspiration from the diverse experiences shared here. Your stories, insights, and feedback are what motivate me to keep pushing forward.

Let’s Connect!

Whether you're an SAP expert or someone who's just started your journey, I’d love to hear about your experiences. What was your "aha" moment when you first discovered SAP? How has SAP transformed the way you approach process optimization? Let's share our stories and keep learning from each other.

SAP SuccessFactors Career and Talent Development Careers

entry.title: ARM Process Issue
entry.content:
Hi SAP Experts,

I’m facing an issue in our Advanced Returns Management (ARM) process where things are not working as expected when using the Replacement refund type in a return order.

What’s happening:

  • I’m creating a return order (type RE2) with refund type Replacement.

  • After the inspection step, the system is supposed to perform Logistical Follow-Up (for example, scrapping and creating a replacement order).

  • In some cases, this works fine.

  • But in other cases, the system tries to create a Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge (SD2) first instead of doing the logistical follow-up.

What’s strange:

  • When SD2 fails, the process stops and shows “Processed with errors”, but there’s no message in the application log (SLG1), and the replacement material checkbox becomes unchecked automatically.

  • Even though I didn’t expect an SD2 at this step, the system still tries to create one.

  • There is no difference in the materials, plant, or inspection lot type — some materials work fine in one case and fail in another.

  • We have only one plant, and this process does not involve a purchase order.

  • When I manually create SD2 using VA01 (with reference to RE2), it works perfectly.

  • Application log says, Follow up Document is still in Progress, MESSAGE 013.

What I need help with:

  • Why is the system trying to create SD2 before the logistical follow-up?

  • Is there a BAPI, BADI, or backend process controlling this that we should check?

  • Where can I find the logic that determines the sequence of steps (SD2 vs logistical follow-up)?

  • How can I prevent SD2 from being triggered when it’s not supposed to?

I’ve already checked logs in SLG1, SM13, and debugged a bit but couldn’t find the root cause.

Any help or direction would be appreciated!

entry.title: Re: Auditing Solution Update for SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform 4.3 +
entry.content: Hello @jennifer_a_szulinski, I believe this is expected because the duration of all queries is 4 minutes; they are usually run in parallel, so the overall duration will be shorter. It won't be the 'max' of any one of those, due to how it all works. For you, the '1 minute' isn't actually stored, at least I don't think it is. Essentially, I'm saying that the auditing database doesn't record the duration of the 'event' when it involves a refresh with multiple data providers, at least that's my current understanding. If you use SYS11, I'd be interested to see what it shows for the duration, as it might change my current thinking. Please share the refresh event as shown in SYS11, and that will help a little. Kind regards, Matthew

entry.title: Deleting an Unused Chart of Accounts in SAP S/4HANA – Blocked by Special Purpose Ledger Usage
entry.content:
Dear SAP Experts,

I intend to delete an unused chart of accounts from our SAP S/4HANA system. When attempting to do so via transaction OB8Y or through the following path in the IMG:

SAP Customizing Implementation Guide → Financial Accounting → General Ledger Accounting → Preparation for Productive Start → New Installation → Delete Test Data → Delete Master Data → Delete Chart of Accounts

I receive the following error message:

"Chart of accounts is used in Special Purpose Ledger. Entries cannot be deleted."

After careful review, I can confirm that this chart of accounts is not in operational use.

My question to the community is:
How can I remove the associated entries in the Special Purpose Ledger (FI-SL) to allow for the complete deletion of the chart of accounts?

I would greatly appreciate any guidance or shared experiences regarding this matter.

Kind regards,

entry.title: Re: How to Hide a Combined Field Group (#AS_FIELDGROUP) b...
entry.content:
Hi Anitha, 

Is that what you mean? If so, I have the same behavior. The field is being shown by default. 

@ui: {
  lineItem: [
      { 
      type: #AS_FIELDGROUP,
        valueQualifier: 'StartEnd',
        label: 'Planned Start / End',
        importance: #LOW
         },
         {  hidden: true
  }
  ],
      fieldGroup: [
      {
      qualifier: 'StartEnd',
        position: 10 }]
  }
  @Consumption:{
      filter.hidden: true
       }
       
  MfgOrderPlannedStartEndDate;
    @ui: {
    lineItem: [
    { hidden: true }
    ],
    fieldGroup: [
    {
    qualifier: 'StartEnd',
      position: 20 }] }
  @Consumption:{
    filter.hidden: true
     }
  MfgOrderPlannedEndStartDate;

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Top of page and end of page using SAP List Viewer (SALV)
entry.content:
Unfortunatley your example does not show TOP-OF-PAGE but TOP-OF-LIST which is quite different.  This is important for printouts as TOP-OF-PAGE appears on every page and TOP-OF-LIST appears only on first page. If the output is displayed on screen only this may be a minor matter. But if you need a printout your example does not help.

Kind regards

Otto

entry.title: Re: 客户对S/4HANA Public Cloud的账套需求
entry.content:
Hello @JuliaLu 

To set up 0L (local GAAP), 2L (Austrian GAAP), and 4G (Chinese GAAP) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you need to:

Scope ledgers during initial setup (CBC):

    • Activate J58 (0L), 1GA (2L), and 2VA (3L – used as 4G).

Ledgers are fixed after go-live.

  1. Assign accounting principles (e.g. LocalGAAP, ATGAAP, CNAP) to the correct ledgers and company codes via SSCUI 101087.
  2. Charts of accounts:Only one operational CoA is allowed. Use alternative G/L accounts and group account numbers for local and group needs.

Consolidation:
Use Group Reporting (scope items 1SG, 3SG) for Austrian and Chinese GAAP group reporting. Map local accounts to group FS items.

Reporting:
Use standard apps by ledger and consolidation unit.

Refer to below helpful SAP Documentations

SAP Help: Parallel Accounting in Public Cloud

Preparing for Universal Parallel Accounting

2844132 - The field "G/L" is greyed out in app Create Incoming Invoices

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: (Custom) Idoc: issue when changing data type of a field
entry.content: @Giovanni-- yes a new basic type to reflect a new version number.

entry.title: Re: BADI Recommendation for Vendor Balance Validation in...
entry.content:
Hi @PTiwari 

Thanks for outlining the requirement.

To enable you restrict FB65 postings based on vendor balances, you can use the following BAdI:

BAdI: MM_IV_ITEM_BADI
Method: CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE

This process allows you implement a logic that retrieves the vendor’s current balance and raises an error if the balance is negative. The check should ensure the balance is ≥ 0 before allowing the invoice to post.


Before you proceed, please ensure that this BADI is available in your tenant via the Custom Logic app. If it is not available, an alternative would be to use a BRF+ validation or a custom extension via BTP.

Below are detailed steps that might be helpful in achieving CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE method:

  1. First, retrieve the vendor number from the invoice header.
  2. Second, call BAPI_VENDOR_GETDETAIL or use CDS view I_Supplier / I_SupplierCompany. This however depends on your system.
  3. Third, check the current balance of the vendor from the BSEG or BSIK/BSIS relevant source. Note that the cloud-friendly version is achieved via CDS or public APIs.
  4. Finally, if balance < 0, raise an error using RAISE EXCEPTION or MESSAGE.

Please note that in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the use of custom code is restricted to released BADIs. Check if MM_IV_ITEM_BADI or MM_IV_HEADER_BADI is released in your system under Extensibility > Custom Logic app.

If not available, an alternative approach is to:

  • Use the Business Rule Framework (BRF+) for validation (if FB65 flows through MM logic).
  • Otherwise, implement pre-checks via a custom CDS-based RAP object or side-by-side check in BTP.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Warm regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: CCM Workflow Report
entry.content:
Hi,

As of now there isn’t a standard report or app in CCM (Continuous Control Monitoring) that directly shows pending workflows per user out of the box.

However, you can try checking the My Inbox app (if configured) for user-specific workflows, or use transaction SWI5 or SWI1 in the backend to track workflow items by user.

If you're using GRC with CCM, you might also be able to create a custom report using tables like SWWUSERWI or SWWIHEAD to list pending items per user.

Would recommend checking with your BASIS or workflow admin to confirm what’s active in your system.

Hope this helps!

entry.title: Association from picklist (Employee Class) to Generic Object (Country) feasibility
entry.content:
Hello experts,

Is there a possibility to associate a GO (Country) to a Picklist (Employee Class) and control the selection in the position (MDF Object)?

Eg:
During a creation of position from CANADA and show only the 4 option we have available to this country for employee class.

CANADA -> Options availlable: A, F, H and J

During a creation of position from UNITED STATES and show only the 4 option we have available to this country for employee class.

CANADA -> Options availlable: B, D, X and Z

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud: Delete/deactivate depreciation area...
entry.content: There is no option of deactivating the depreciation areas in this sscuid 102609 in SAP Public cloud

entry.title: Re: SAP Screen Personas Errors in log
entry.content: Create a support incident and provide access to the system where the problem is reproducible.

entry.title: Re: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content: I need to ask that one question, everyone is talking about: organizations can already tackle these challenges using their existing system landscape. It may include the SAC, Datasphere and/or a BW/4HANA. How is the BDC (excluding DSP and SAC in the context of this question) really helping solve business challenges that currently cannot be dealt with? I do not want to criticize or diminish BDC, I’m just really keen to sell it to someone who is not only looking for the technical advantages (or potentially lower TCO).
